overview_summary: The sole profiled neighbor has shown support for renewable energy on their ranch and holds a strong standing in the community. This individual is a high-influence member of the area as a multi-generational rancher engaged in local and state-level issues.

neighbors.name: Jason Thornock & Tracy Thornock
neighbors.claims: Jason and Tracy Thornock are third-generation ranchers in the Cokeville area of Lincoln County, Wyoming [Wyoming Public Media](https://www.wyomingpublicmedia.org/natural-resources-energy/2025-12-17/ranchers-hoping-solar-can-lower-costs-say-utilities-and-the-state-stand-in-their-way) [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/wyoming/supreme-court/2016/s-15-0273.html). They have actively pursued on-site renewable energy, including applying for federal grants to build a large solar array and supporting state legislation to expand net metering for ranch-scale solar systems [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/). Jason Thornock testified to state lawmakers that Rocky Mountain Power’s actions nearly bankrupted his ranching business, and he later lost a court battle over those utility disputes which left him paying the company’s legal fees [Wyoming Public Media](https://www.wyomingpublicmedia.org/natural-resources-energy/2025-12-17/ranchers-hoping-solar-can-lower-costs-say-utilities-and-the-state-stand-in-their-way).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through a respected fellow rancher or trusted community leader. Emphasize how the project can help sustain their family ranch for future generations while allowing local input and control, aligning with their values of independence and legacy.
